Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Assessing chemical and microbiological contamination in environmental waters in Eastern North Carolina after Hurricane Florence

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane Florence passed through southeast North Carolina in 2018 resulting in widespread flooding. The counties most affected by flooding house thousands of swine and poultry confined animal feeding operations (CAFOs). These areas are also home to many low-income, African American, Hispanic, and American Indian communities. The objective of this research is to study the spread of contaminants into the environment caused by Hurricane floodwaters. The pollutants assessed include heavy metals from coal ash, emerging chemical contaminants related to industrial and municipal wastewater, and pathogens and nutrients associated with CAFOs. This project will result in improved understanding of the risks posed by extreme flooding. Local communities affected by the flooding will be engaged in this research through the identification of sampling sites and communication of research results. The results will have broader impact through the identification of waste management operations that can be modified to prevent such releases in future flooding events.

The central aim of this work is to assess microbial and chemical contamination of the environment near livestock and industrial operations flooding caused by Hurricane Florence floodwaters. A secondary aim is to understand the relative impacts of different land-usage and livestock waste management practices on contaminant loading. To achieve these aims, this research project has the following objectives: (1) Collect samples to quantify spatiotemporal variability in molecular targets for microbial contamination (i.e., human-, poultry-, and swine-specific fecal microbial source tracking targets and antimicrobial resistance genes), nutrients (N and P), heavy metals, and chemical contaminants of emerging concern; (2) Identify spatial relationships between contamination, flooding extent, land-use (e.g., CAFO densities, industrial sites, urban areas) and manure management practices using satellite imagery and machine learning techniques; (3) Assess persistence of biological and chemical species in the natural environment post-flooding. To achieve these objectives, the research team will sample across 50 sites in multiple coastal plain river basins where intense flooding occurred after Hurricane Florence to map advanced chemical and biological water quality indicators in high spatial resolution. The team sampled within a week after the hurricane, and then will sample after ~1 month, ~2 months, and ~6 months. Knowledge gained from this study will directly inform improvements to emergency management protocols post-hurricane in landscapes with many contaminant sources. The work will have broader impact through the promulgation of waste management recommendations that account for the increasing likelihood and severity of extreme flooding events expected in the future as our climate changes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project studied the potential spread of contaminants into the environment by floodwaters following Hurricane Florence’s path through eastern North Carolina (NC) in September of 2018. Targeted contaminants include pathogens and nutrients associated with waste products of concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs), slaughterhouses, septic tanks, and wastewater treatment facilities. In addition, screening was conducted to detect emerging chemical contaminants associated with industrial facilities and other operations. The counties most affected by Florence house thousands of swine lagoons and sprayfields, as well as poultry operations; in addition, these areas are home to marginalized communities, including a large African American population, a growing Hispanic population, and a majority of NC’s American Indian population.

 

The study aimed to assess the impacts of flooding caused by Hurricane Florence on microbial and chemical contamination in environmental waters near livestock and industrial operations in Florence-affected areas of NC, and to explain the relative impacts of different land-uses on contaminant loading.

 

To achieve this aim, the research team carried out the following research objectives: (1) Collect samples to quantify spatiotemporal variability in culture-based and molecular-based targets for microbial contamination (i.e., enteric pathogens, human-, poultry-, and swine-specific fecal microbial source tracking targets and antimicrobial resistance genes), nutrients (N and P), heavy metals (e.g., Pb) and chemical contaminants of emerging concern; (2) Identify spatial relationships between contamination, flooding extent, land-use (e.g., CAFO densities, industrial sites, urban areas) and manure management practices using satellite imagery and machine learning techniques; (3) Assess persistence of biological and chemical species in the natural environment post-flooding.

 

 

The research team sampled 45 sites in multiple river basins where intense post-Florence flooding occurred to map chemical and biological water quality indicators in high spatial resolution.  The team sampled within a week after the hurricane, and then 1 month later (phase 1 and phase 2 sampling). The team sampled the same sites approximately one year later and sampled twice, one-month apart (phases 3 and 4). The phases 3 and 4 sampling occurred at a time when there was limited prior rainfall within a 7-day window.

 

We found high levels of fecal contamination as measured by E. coli in surface water after Hurricane Florence. Concentrations were similar between September and October 2019 sampling phases (Phases 1 and 2). On average, floodplain waters showed better microbial water quality in October as compared to September 2019. Channel waters were comparable between these two sample phases. We detected evidence of human and swine fecal contamination in the surface waters, and prevalence of these targets was similar between September and October of 2019. A separate analysis of samples by collaborators revealed the presence of Arcobacter butzleri, a pathogen associated with both human and livestock waste, in a majority of Phase 1 and 2 samples. In the sub-set of samples screened using a non-targeted analysis of chemicals, almost 2000 different chemical compounds were detected. Plasticizers and other related compounds used in the production of plastics and polymers as well as products from industrial processes were frequently found in surface waters from Lumber, Neuse and Cape Fear Rivers. Perfluoroalklyl substances (PFAS) and other perfluoro-related compounds were also present in surface water in all three rivers. Metabolites associated with herbicides and pesticides were detected at some sites, and exhibited variation over temporal and spatial scales.

 

Further analysis comparing chemical and microbiological contamination will be conducted. In addition, geospatial modeling is underway to identify relationships between risk factors (e.g., CAFO concentration, distance to wastewater treatment plant, flooding extent) and water quality parameters.

 

This project identified areas with high levels of microbial contamination and expansive signatures of chemical contaminants in surface and floodwaters after Hurricane Florence. Based on the microbial source tracking results, some sites had both human and swine fecal markers detected whereas others only had the fecal marker of one host detected or none at all. This highlights the spatial variability of contamination, and how certain spots in a watershed may be more prone to contamination after extreme flooding events.  In addition, the differences in contamination through the different phases of the study highlight the need for higher temporal resolution sampling, to better understand the temporal dynamics of contamination after extreme flooding. This study improved our understanding of risks posed by hurricane-induced flooding by characterizing the chemical and biological quality of flood waters and surface waters.  Local communities were engaged in the identification of sampling sites and communication of results, and the research team strives to continue to strengthen relationships with the various stakeholders and provide useful information to the communities. Knowledge gained from this study will directly inform improvements to emergency management protocols post-hurricane in landscapes with many contaminant sources and multiple land uses. In addition, waste management recommendations will be developed which take into account the increasing likelihood and severity of extreme flooding events expected in the future as our climate changes.
